tutorials.name: Colors and Themes
tutorials.blurb:
Learn how to use the THEME command to enhance your
                       playing experience with custom, shareable color
                       palettes.
tutorials.finish: You have completed the Colors and Themes tutorial.

steps.prompt: Familiarize yourself with the THEME command by typing it with no arguments: ^TTHEME.
Use THEME PREVIEW to see what your current theme looks like in action: ^TTHEME PREVIEW
Use THEME SHOW to see where these color assignments are made: ^TTHEME SHOW

Each theme is made up of a PALETTE and CHANNELS.
    * A PALETTE is a set of 16 select colors that define a curated set of 
      colors that match the theme's concept.
    * CHANNELS are the different kinds of information that can be sent to
      you, and can be themed using references to the palette, or with colors
      not already on the palette.
      
Mud98 has several built in palettes. Use THEME LIST to view the ones 
available to you: ^TTHEME LIST

Look at the list of themes, and see if one look interesting to you. Use 
THEME PREVIEW to see what it would look like on your screen. Remember
that you can also refer other people's public themes by putting '@name' 
before the theme name: ^TTHEME PREVIEW <theme name>

If that theme doesn't suit your fancy, try previewing others until you find
one you like. When you've settled on one, select it with THEME SELECT (note
that the rest of this tutorial assumes you chose a 24-bit theme). Type: 
^TTHEME SELECT <theme name>

You'll see some changes right away. Let's use THEME SHOW to take a compre-
hensive look at your new theme: ^TTHEME SHOW.

Enter the theme editor so you can customize this palette. The editor lets
you adjust colors, rename the theme, and save all your work without
retyping THEME before every command. Type: ^TTHEME EDIT

Are all of the colors in the palette to your liking? If not, you can easily
change them using the PALETTE command while THEME EDIT is active.
Choose a color swatch on the palette you want to change and refer to that
swatch by its slot number (shown on THEME SHOW).

Next, decide on a new color. In a 16-bit theme, this is a number 0-16. On
a 256-color palette, its a number 0-256. Since we are working with a 24-bit
theme, we can use numbers in "#RRGGBB;" hex format (remember the semicolon;
it's required). For instance, Slate Blue is "#6A5ACD;".

Try changing one of the palette swatches with your chosen color: ^TPALETTE
<swatch number> <#xxxxxx;>  ^*Ex: palette 8 #DB7E86;

Notice that changing the palette swatch also changed all the channels that
referred to that swatch. This is handy way to create a whole new theme in
a matter of minutes, simply by switching out the swatches.

Right now you're working with your own personal copy of the theme. Your
changes only apply to you, and they aren't saved automatically. For now,
try discarding your changes: ^TDISCARD

Maybe you like a theme's colors, but not how it's using them. We can change
what colors are applied to each channel with the CHANNEL command inside
THEME EDIT.

Look at THEME SHOW and pick a channel you'd like to change (by name, so 
like "say_text", for instance). Then choose a fresh color in "#RRGGBB;"
format that fits your concept.

Try assigning a new color to the channel: ^TCHANNEL <channel> <#xxxxxx;>

Now that you've customized your theme, you should use the editor's NAME
command to give it a new name: ^TNAME <name>

Your theme selections and changes only apply to your current session. You 
have to save them from inside the editor. Save your changes to the theme
(you can delete it later): ^TSAVE

Now that you have your theme saved, you can use the editor to make it visible
and available to others while you are online (you can disable this later):
^TPUBLIC

Other players won't see your theme until you save the settings change: 
^TSAVE

When you're done editing, leave the theme editor so you can use the other
THEME commands again: ^TDONE

Look at the list of themes available to you now and see that your customized
theme is listed (and marked public): ^TTHEME LIST

You can get rid of unwanted themes at any time. This is useful, as you have
a limit of 10 personal color themes (not counting public and system themes,
which do not take up your slots.

Before you can remove your new theme, however, you have to stop using it.
Switch another theme: ^TTHEME SELECT <name>

Use THEME REMOVE to delete your custom theme (using its FULL name):
^TTHEME REMOVE <name>
